datafield.subfield: The collection consists primarily of music (ms., facsimile, and printed) and accompanying correspondence, programs, and reviews. The majority of the music in the collection comprises facsimile scores of compositions commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra from prominent American composers, such as Dominick Argento, Milton Babbitt, Henry Cowell, Jacob Druckman, Ross Lee Finney, Lukas Foss, Leon Kirchner, Ernst Krenek, Robert Hall Lewis, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Christopher Rouse, Gunther Schuller, Ralph Shapey, Hugo Weisgall, and Charles Wuorinen. Many of these scores are inscribed to Mr. Rothschild and signed by their composers. The collection also includes holograph ms. scores by Henry Cowell, Hugo Weisgall, and Brown Benson. Correspondence accompanies the scores by David Epstein, John Huggler, Jean Eichelberger Ivey, Leo Kraft, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Ralph Shapey, and Hugo Weisgall. Besides the correspondence, a few scores include programs and reviews of the concerts at which they were performed.

did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Extent
physdesc.extent: circa 225 items
11 boxes
6 linear feet

did.abstract: The collection consists primarily of music (ms., facsimile, and printed) and accompanying correspondence, programs, and reviews. The majority of the music in the collection comprises facsimile scores of compositions commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra from prominent American composers, such as Dominick Argento, Milton Babbitt, Henry Cowell, Jacob Druckman, Ross Lee Finney, Lukas Foss, Leon Kirchner, Ernst Krenek, Robert Hall Lewis, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Christopher Rouse, Gunther Schuller, Ralph Shapey, Hugo Weisgall, and Charles Wuorinen. Many of these scores are inscribed to Mr. Rothschild and signed by their composers. The collection also includes holograph ms. scores by Henry Cowell, Hugo Weisgall, and Brown Benson. Correspondence accompanies the scores by David Epstein, John Huggler, Jean Eichelberger Ivey, Leo Kraft, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Ralph Shapey, and Hugo Weisgall. Besides the correspondence, a few scores include programs and reviews of the concerts at which they were performed.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: Chamber Music Society of Baltimore--Records and correspondence.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Randolph S. Rothschild Collection was processed in 2003 by Wilda Heiss. This Finding Aid was prepared with Corel WordPerfect 8. In 2003, Michael A. Ferrando coded and edited the finding aid for EAD format.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Randolph S. Rothschild Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Randolph S. Rothschild Collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Performing Arts Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use. Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Randolph S. Rothschild Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: Randolph S. Rothschild (1909-2003) spent his life as a champion of new music. Toward this end, he was involved in the commissioning of an unusually large numbers of new musical works through his presidency of the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore from 1954 to 1993 and his membership on the board of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra from the 1960s when Peter Herman Adler was the music director and conductor through the directorship of Sergiu Comissiona and David Zinman.

Rothschild started piano lessons at the age of eight at the Peabody Preparatory of the Peabody Institute (which is now affiliated with the Johns Hopkins University) with Nellie Wilder Coolidge Robinson Robinson until he was 18. Afterwards, he attended the Johns Hopkins University for two years where he became a jazz pianist for the Blue Jay Student Jazz Orchestra. He finished his undergraduate Bachelor of Science degree in Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, Wharton School. He began his law degree at the University of Pennsylvania, but returned to Baltimore during the depression where he completed the law degree at the University of Maryland.

In 1936 he joined the Sun Life Insurance Company of America which was founded in 1890 by his father Solomon and uncle Moses Rothschild. When the company was sold in 1972, he retired from the posts of vice president and general counsel.

During these working years, his involvement in the musical life of Baltimore continued. From 1954 to 1993 he served as president of the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore, which was co-founded in 1949 by Hugo Weisgall and Richard Goodman. He was a board member of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and served on the committee that suggested contemporary composers for new commissions by the orchestra. Since 1978, he served on the board of the Peabody Institute and later became a member of the Advisory Council. He has made generous gifts to Peabody as part of their major campaign in 1980 and endowed the Composition Department to champion new music through the Randolph S. Rothschild Fund which supports scholarships, a visiting professorship for guest composers, and the printing and recording of specially selected student compositions. In 1992, he was awarded the George Peabody Medal for "outstanding contributions to music in America" by the Peabody Institute.

His work on behalf of the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra to commission works by contemporary composers created his lifetime musical legacy. He and his wife, Amalie, frequently invited the composers to their home as house guests during their stay in Baltimore. They also hosted musical performances at their home. In the late 1940s, he set up a professional recording studio in his home which overlooked the performing area and which originally had the capacity to cut LPs and 16-inch transcription discs and later switched to open-reel and cassette recordings. He recorded not only the performances at his home, but also recorded off-the-air performances of world premieres and first performances of newly commissioned works.

Rothschild was also well known as a micromineralogist and longtime editor of the International Directory of Micromounters. He has cut and mounted more than 7,000 crystals which require a microscope to view and appreciate their beauty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Randolph S. Rothschild Collections consists primarily of music (manuscript, facsimile, and printed) and accompanying correspondence, programs, and reviews. The collection spans the years 1942 to 1992, with the bulk of the materials dating from 1973 to 1985.

The majority of the music in the collection comprises facsimile scores of compositions commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra from prominent American composers, such as Dominick Argento, Milton Babbitt, Henry Cowell, Jacob Druckman, Ross Lee Finney, Lukas Foss, Leon Kirchner, Ernst Krenek, Robert Hall Lewis, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Christopher Rouse, Gunther Schuller, Ralph Shapey, Hugo Weisgall, Charges Wuorinen among others. Many of these scores are inscribed to Mr. Rothschild and signed by the composer. The collection also includes holograph manuscript scores by Henry Cowell, Hugo Weisgall, and Brown Benson. A few scores were sent as a complimentary copy from the publisher to Mr. Randolph.

Correspondence accompanies the scores by David Epstein, John Huggler, Jean Eichelberger Ivey, Leo Kraft, Lawrence Moss, Roger Reynolds, Ralph Shapey, and Hugo Weisgall. Besides the correspondence, a few scores include programs and reviews of the concerts.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Randolph S. Rothschild Collection
arrangement.p: The Randolph S. Rothschild Collection is organized in 1 series:

scopecontent.p: The Music series consists primarily of music (manuscript, facsimile, and printed) and accompanying correspondence, programs, and reviews.

arrangement.p: Arrangement is alphabetically by composer and by title.

unittitle.title: Concerto for cello and orchestra (1990)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, plastic & paper covers; [1], 140 p.

note.p: Inscribed on t.p.: To Randy Rothschild, With all my thanks for the great opportunity of working with both a great cellist and a great conductor. The Baltimore Symphony, however, was the indispensable element in this chemistry. With Respect, [Signed] Stephen Albert

Also, inscribed on t.p.: Thank you Randy for this wonderful work. [Signed] David Zinman; To Randy Rothschild, I am deeply grateful to you for giving all of us this wonderful new work. [Signed] Yo Yo Ma
Note: [Commissioned by the Baltimore Symphony Orchetra]

unittitle.title: Le tombeau d'Edgar Poe: suite for orchestra (1985)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; [3], 80 p.

note.p: Inscribed on t.p.: Commissioned by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and Dedicated to Randolph S. Rothschild and Joseph Meyerhoff; 1st performance by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, February 27, 1986 with David Zinman conducting. [Signed] Dominick Argento, December 10, 1985
On cover label & p. i: Boosey & Hawkes
On p. ii: Commissioned by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra; David Zinman, music director

unittitle.title: The head of the bed for soprano, flute, clarinet, violin, and violoncello (1981)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; poem by John Hollander; [1], 75 p.

note.p: Inscribed on p. i: For Randy Rothschild, In great gratitude, from [Signed] Milton Babbitt, 1/27/82
Also, on p. i: Commissioned by and Dedicated to The Chamber Music Society of Baltimore and its President, Randolph S. Rothschild, and composed for Phyllis Bryn-Julson

unittitle.title: Randy's hit tune (1989)

physdesc.extent: Lead sheet [for guitar], holograph ms. in ink; [1] p.

note.p: On p. 1: Commissioned by Jean and Gilbert Benson for Randy's 80th; June 25th 1989

unittitle.title: Three years from nowhere for violin and piano (1983)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; 11 p.

note.p: On cover: possibly composer's autograph label
Note: [Commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Baltimore]

physdesc.extent: Full score, printed (Edition Moeck, no. 5139), unbound, paper cover; [5] p. (2 copies)

note.p: Stamped on cover: Complimentary copy

note.p: Inscribed on t.p.: To Randy Rothschild In gratitude for all the help he's given me! [Signed] Gordon C. Cyr

note.p: Inscribed on p. 1: for Randy in continued gratitude for his wisdom and generosity in the cause of new music, 11/26/77, [Signed] Larry Moss
Laid in: a.l.s., from Lawrence Moss to Randolph Rothschild, 26 November 1977

unittitle.title: Suite française pour piano d'apres Claude Gervaise (16 siècle) (c1935)

physdesc.extent: Score, printed (Durand & Cie.), bound paper covers; [1], 15 p.

unittitle.title: Toy concertino (c1967)

physdesc.extent: Full score, printed (Broude Bros. Contemporary Composers, Study Score Series, No. 12), bound, paper covers; [3], 42 p.

note.p: Laid in: photocopy, t.l.s., from Irving Broude; Inscribed: Rec'd 3/10/67 R.S.R.

Note: for 2 fl., ob., 2 cl., bsn., 2 hn., 2 tpt., timp., strs. with concertino of 8 players tin fife, picc. tpt., 2 ocarinas, toy glock., bird warble, toy sn. dr., cuckoo call/toy accdn., concertina, harmonica

unittitle.title: Islands from archipelago, I. Summer island (1984) for solo oboe and tape

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms. (C. F. Peters Corporation), bound, paper covers; [1],11 p.

note.p: Inscribed on p. 1: for Randolph Rothschild with appreciation and admiration [Signed] Roger Reynolds
Note: Commissioned by Randolph S. Rothschild for oboist, James Ostryniec
Laid in: a.l.s., from Reynolds to Rothschild, 2 September 1984
Laid in: t.l.s., from Rothschild to Reynolds, 4 September 1984
Laid in: a.l.s., from Reynolds to Rothschild, 8 July 1985
Laid in: t.l.s., from Rothschild to Reynolds, 1 August 1985

unittitle.title: Karolju for large SATB chorus and orchestra (1991)

note.p: Inscribed on t.p.: For Randolph and Amalie Rothschild, with admiration, affection, and gratitude. [Signed], Christopher Rouse, 11/7/91
On verso of t.p.: Commissioned by Baltimore Symphony Orchestra with the assistance of Randolph Rothschild and the Barlow Foundation for Music Composition at Brigham Young University

Laid in: Invitation to pre-concert dinner, 11/8/91; 3 photocopies of review, Baltimore Sun, 11/7/91; 3 photocopies of review, Baltimore Sun, 11/8/91; Overture program and insert, November-December 1991

unittitle.title: Triplum II: three lyric pieces for instrumental trios and orchestra (1975)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; 75 p.

note.p: Inscribed on p. 1: To Randy, with affection and gratitude. [Signed] Gunther Schuller
Also, on p. 1: Dedicated to Sergiu Comissiona and the Baltimore Symphony

unittitle.title: Three for six (1979)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., one bound, paper covers; [2], 73 p. (2 copies; one for piano, one for conductor)

note.p: On t.p.: Commissioned by Chamber Music Society of Baltimore
Also, on t.p.: Dedicated to Robert Black & the New York New Music Ensemble
On front cover: On rental only, Theodore Presser Company
Laid in: a.l.s., from Ralph Shapey to Randolph Rothschild, 11 March 1981
Note: scored for fl./picc., cl./b.cl., vln./vla., vnc., pno., perc

physdesc.extent: Parts, facsimile ms., each folded, no covers; 8 p. (fl./picc.), 9 p. (cl./b.cl.), 11 p. (vln./vla.), 9 p. (vnc.), 15 p. (perc.)

unittitle.title: Symphony no. 5: "Visions of time" (1971)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; [2], 90 p.

note.p: Inscribed on verso of t.p.: For Randy Rothschild and Amalie Rothschild, warm friends of music and the composer, whose gracious support made this symphony possible. With cordial greetings, [Signed] Elie Siegmeister
On t.p.: Commissioned by The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Sergiu Comissiona, conductor, and first performed at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, D.C., on May 2, 1977

unittitle.title: Fancies and inventions for barytone and five instruments(1969-70)

physdesc.extent: Full score, holograph ms. in pencil on vellum, unbound; from the Hesperides (1648) by Robert Herrick; 54 p. [added measure clipped to end of p. 20]

note.p: On t.p.: To Randolph S. Rothschild as a [illegible] appreciation for his many years of continued artistic support. [Signed] Hugo Weisgall
Laid in: 2 cards with composer's name and title of work; one manila envelope
For: flute, clarinet, viola, violoncello, and piano

unittitle.title: Fancies and inventions for barytone and five instruments(1969-70)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., unbound; [1], 54 p.

note.p: Laid in: (1) photocopy review of 11/1/70 concert;

Laid in: (2) t.l.s., from Hugo Weisgall to Randolph Rothschild with envelope [Signed] Hugo, 3 Nov. 1970, 1 p.; a.l.s., from Hugo Weisgall to Randolph Rothschild [Signed] N. Weisgall for Hugo, 16 Nov. 1970, 1 p.; t.l., from Randolph Rothschild to Hugo Weisgall [Unsigned], 23 Nov. 1970, 1 p.;

Laid in: (3) a.l.s., in the hand of N. Weisgall from Hugo Weisgall to Randolph Rothschild [Signed] Hugo, 13 Dec. 1970, 1 leaf; program from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Concerts 1970/1971; New York Times review, 12/11/70; New York Times advertisement, 12/6/70 (2 copies);

Laid in: (4) t.l.s., from Randolph Rothschild to Hugo Wesigall [Signed] Randy, 11 Jan. 1971; t.l.s., from Hugo Weisgall to Randolph Rothschild [Signed] Hugo, Jan. 6, 1971, with envelope; review from New York Magazine, 11 Jan. 1971;
Laid in: (5) Peabody News article, re Commencement 1973 in which Hugo Weisgall received honorary degree of Doctor of Music

unittitle.title: Four birthday cards for piano (1986)

physdesc.extent: Score, printed (Theodore Presser Company), bound, paper covers; 8 p.

note.p: Note: includes 1. Billy's Belated Birthday Rag (William Schuman), 2. For Randy at 70 (Randolph S. Rothschild), 3. Valse Oubliée (Arnold Broido), 4. Rückblick (dedicated to Roger Sessions)

unittitle.title: Graven images no. 10. For Randy at 70 for piano (1970)

physdesc.extent: Score, holograph ms. in pencil, unbound, no cover; 2 p.

note.p: Laid in: a.l.s., from Hugo Weisgall to Randolph Rothschild, 13 September 1979

unittitle.title: Love's wounded: two songs for baritone and orchestra (1986)

physdesc.extent: Full score, facsimile ms., bound, paper covers; from the Hebrew Judam Halevi, English version by Raymond Scheindlin; [2], 60 p.

note.p: Inscribed on t.p.: To Randy, Old friend and supporter to whom this should have gone in the first place. [Signed] Hugo, 9/19/86, Balto.

Also, on t.p.: Commissioned by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, David Zinman, Music Director; This work was first performed by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra on Sept. 18 and 19, 1986 with David Zinman conducting and David Hamilton, baritone
Laid in: a.l.s., from Martha Batehelor of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, to Randolph Rothschild, n.d.
Also, laid in: program, Overture, Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, vol. 71, no. 1, September 18-November 8, 1986

note.p: On t.p.: Commissioned by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and dedicated to Randolph S. Rothschild and Joseph Meyerhoff. First performed by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra on May 9, 1985, with David Zinman conducting
Laid in: Business card [attached to C. F. Peters Corporation insert] from Ann Goldberg, Music Administrator of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra
Laid in: Randy, This is for you fr. the publisher. [Signed] Ann
Laid in: "Musical Events: Courtesy, Humanity, Hardiness," The New Yorker, May 27, 1985; p. 85-90
